questions.question: What transfers data between devices?
questions.explanation: USB: standard interface. Versions: USB 2.0, 3.0, 3.1, 4.0 (improving speed). Power: supplies electricity. Connectors: Type-A, Type-B, Type-C. Devices: keyboards, mice, storage, monitors. Backward compatible: older devices work (slower).

questions.question: What connects to networks?
questions.explanation: Network adapter: Ethernet or WiFi. Speed: measured Mbps (megabits/second). Ethernet: wired, reliable, faster. WiFi: wireless, convenient, slower. Driver: OS software needed. Configuration: IP, DNS settings. Redundancy: multiple NICs possible.

questions.question: What renders graphics?
questions.explanation: Graphics card: processes visual data. Memory: VRAM (video memory). Performance: measured TFLOPS. Cooling: GPU heats up. Driver: software required. Gaming: high-end cards for performance. Professional: specialized cards for accuracy. Integration: many CPUs have integrated graphics.

questions.question: What manages device communication?
questions.explanation: Chipset: coordinates components. Northbridge: CPU communication (high-speed). Southbridge: I/O (legacy term, now PCH). Modern: single chip integration. Buses: connect via chipset. Performance: affects overall speed. Design: determines capabilities.

questions.question: What stores BIOS?
questions.explanation: ROM: permanent, non-volatile storage. BIOS: firmware stored here. Capacity: typically small (few MB). Purpose: initialization, boot sequence. Updates: possible (flash ROM). Importance: critical for system startup. Failure: cannot boot.

questions.question: What manages power states?
questions.explanation: Power management: reduces power consumption. States: sleep, hibernation, off. Benefits: energy savings, environmental. Implementation: OS + hardware coordination. Wake: triggers return to full power. Importance: laptop battery life critical.

questions.question: What stores credentials?
questions.explanation: TPM: secure chip storing credentials. Purpose: encryption keys, passwords. Security: isolated from main system. Benefits: malware protection, secure boot. Implementation: hardware-based. Modern: standard inclusion. Importance: enterprise security.

questions.question: What provides battery power?
questions.explanation: Battery: portable power source. Capacity: measured mAh. Lifespan: degrades over time. Chemistry: Li-ion standard. Management: charging circuits optimize. Health: degrades with cycles. Replacement: necessary eventually.

questions.question: What connects external displays?
questions.explanation: Display ports: HDMI, DisplayPort, VGA, DVI. HDMI: common standard. DisplayPort: gaming/professional. DVI: older, phasing out. VGA: very old (analog). Modern: USB-C carries video. Resolution: port supports maximum. Multiple: daisy-chaining possible.

questions.question: What maintains system clock?
questions.explanation: RTC: keeps time when powered off. CMOS battery: small coin-cell backup. Purpose: system time accuracy. Drift: accumulates without adjustment. NTP: network time protocol syncs. Importance: time-dependent operations need accurate time.
